What are the EXACT steps to configure auto-swap for Azure App Service deployment slots?

A) Create slot → Enable auto-swap → Configure warm-up → Test
B) Configure warm-up → Create slot → Enable auto-swap → Deploy  
C) Create slot → Deploy → Enable auto-swap → Configure warm-up
D) Enable auto-swap → Create slot → Configure warm-up → Deploy
Back: A) Create slot → Enable auto-swap → Configure warm-up → Test Correct Answer: A The correct sequence is: 1. Create deployment slot (staging) 2. Enable Auto-Swap during slot creation OR in deployment settings 3. Configure automatic warm-up process before swap 4. Test to ensure zero-downtime deployment works This ensures proper integration with CI/CD pipelines and fail-safe rollback capabilities.

You need to securely connect an App Service to Azure SQL Database. What is the CORRECT sequence?

A) Service Endpoint → VNet Integration → Firewall Rules → Disable Public Access → Test
B) VNet Integration → Service Endpoint → Firewall Rules → Disable Public Access → Test  
C) Firewall Rules → VNet Integration → Service Endpoint → Disable Public Access → Test
D) Disable Public Access → VNet Integration → Service Endpoint → Firewall Rules → Test
Back: B) VNet Integration → Service Endpoint → Firewall Rules → Disable Public Access → Test Correct Answer: B The sequence is: C→A→D→B→E - C - VNet Integration: Connect App Service to VNet subnet FIRST - A - Service Endpoint: Enable Microsoft.Sql service endpoint - D - Firewall Rules: Update SQL Database firewall rules - B - Disable Public Access: Turn off public internet access - E - Test: Verify end-to-end secure connection CRITICAL: Must establish VNet integration and service endpoints BEFORE disabling public access.

What is Azure Container Instances (ACI) scaling limitation compared to AKS?

A) ACI supports horizontal auto-scaling like AKS
B) ACI requires manual scaling by updating container specifications
C) ACI has no scaling support - containers are fixed size
D) ACI requires delete/redeploy for scaling changes
Back: D) ACI requires delete/redeploy for scaling changes Correct Answer: D ACI Fundamental Limitation: NO in-place auto-scaling support ACI Scaling Process: 1. Delete existing container group (az container delete) 2. Modify deployment template with new specs (CPU, memory, container count) 3. Redeploy container group (az container create) vs AKS: In-place Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) with zero downtime Choose AKS for production workloads requiring auto-scaling.

What are the different Container Apps ingress configuration options?

A) Public, Private, Internal, Disabled
B) External, Internal, Disabled
C) Internet, VNet, Private, None
D) Public, VNet-only, Private, Background
Back: B) External, Internal, Disabled Correct Answer: B External Ingress: • Exposes app to internet traffic • Provides public FQDN • Use for: Public-facing APIs, web applications Internal Ingress: • VNet-only access - no internet exposure • Private connectivity within Container Apps Environment • Use for: Internal microservices, backend APIs Disabled: • No HTTP ingress at all • Use for: Background jobs, queue processors

What is the correct difference between Fault Domains and Update Domains?

A) Fault Domains = power/network failure protection, Update Domains = planned maintenance isolation
B) Fault Domains = planned maintenance isolation, Update Domains = power/network failure protection  
C) Both provide the same protection against different types of failures
D) Fault Domains are for VMs, Update Domains are for containers
Back: A) Fault Domains = power/network failure protection, Update Domains = planned maintenance isolation Correct Answer: A Fault Domains (FD): • Protection against unplanned hardware failures • Separate power source and network switch • Azure automatically distributes VMs across fault domains Update Domains (UD): • Protection during planned maintenance/updates • Only one update domain rebooted at a time • Ensures service availability during Azure maintenance Key: FD = unplanned failures, UD = planned maintenance

What are the differences between VMSS Orchestration Modes?

A) Uniform = identical VMs, Flexible = mixed VM sizes and types
B) Uniform = automatic scaling, Flexible = manual scaling
C) Uniform = single VM type, Flexible = multiple availability zones  
D) No difference - both modes work identically
Back: A) Uniform = identical VMs, Flexible = mixed VM sizes and types Correct Answer: A Uniform Orchestration Mode: • All VMs must be identical (same size, image, configuration) • Built for true scale sets with identical workloads • Traditional VMSS behavior Flexible Orchestration Mode: • Mix different VM sizes and types in same scale set • Better for heterogeneous workloads • More flexibility in VM configuration • Can manage existing VMs Choose Uniform for identical workloads, Flexible for mixed requirements.
